div.p: Image segmentation is a vital and fundamental step in Geographic Object-Based Image Analysis (GEOBIA). Many multiscale segmentation algorithms have been widely used in high resolution (HR) remote sensing images. These segmentation algorithms need a preset parameter, named scale parameter, to control the average size of each object. However, due to the spatial variation, single scale parameter can hardly describe the boundaries of regions with different land covers. To overcome this limitation, in this study, an adaptive parameter optimization method is proposed for multiscale segmentation. To find the optimal scale of objects, a local spectral heterogeneity measure is applied by calculating the spectral angle between inter and intra objects. Different from selecting a global optimal scale parameter, this study aims to directly search the optimal objects from results of all different scales and combine them into final segmentation results. In experiments, a multi-resolution segmentation is used to generate segmentation results of different scales and the QuickBird-2 images are used as test data. Optimization results over four HR test images reveal that the proposed method provides better segmentation performance than single scale segmentation result.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: With the rapid development of remote sensing image technology, more and more high resolution (HR) remote sensing imageries have been acquired and processed. Pixel-based methods are first used in remote sensing image processing by distinguishing land covers with the spectral reflectance (Pu and Landry, 2012). However, the pixel-based methods fail to exploit the spatial variation in HR images because the relations between neighboring pixels are usually ignored. Therefore, the (Geographic) Object-Based Image Analysis (OBIA or GEOBIA) has emerged and become an effective approach in HR image analysis (Hossain and Chen, 2019;Ma et al., 2017;Blaschke et al., 2014).

GEOBIA-based methods consider image objects instead of pixels as basic analysis units (Chen et al., 2018). The purpose of GEOBIA is to address the complicated spatial and hierarchical relationships in the HR image classification process (Ma et al., 2015;Dronova, 2015;Costa et al., 2017). As a vital and fundamental step in GEOBIA, image segmentation aims to divide the pixels into several homogeneous regions. These regions are recognized as objects of GEOBIA and usually represent a kind of land covers such as farm lands, buildings and water bodies (Yang et al., 2015a). Therefore, the segmentation performance has a critical effect on the later steps of GEOBIA, including object feature extraction and classification (Gonçalves et al., 2019).

There are a number of HR image segmentation algorithms proposed and utilized in GEOBIA (Liu et al., 2015;Grinias et al., 2016;Troya-Galvis et al., 2018;Comaniciu and Meer, 2002). For example, watershed segmentation (Li et al., 2010), hybrid segmentation (Wang et al., 2018) and multi-resolution segmentation (Benz et al., 2004) have been widely used to generate image objects in GEOBIA. Most of these segmentation algorithms need to assign a scale parameter to control the size of objects. However, due to the spatial variations in HR images, it is difficult for users to select an appropriate scale for segmentation. The selection of scale parameter usually depends on the trial-and-error method.

To select an appropriate scale for segmentation, researchers proposed a variety of scale optimization methods (Georganos et al., 2018a;Hu et al., 2018). Theses scale optimization methods usually can be divided into two groups: supervised and unsupervised methods (Grybas et al., 2017). Supervised scale optimization methods are designed to measure the similarity between segmentation objects and the reference objects (usually hand digitized by user) (Tian and Chen, 2007;Liu et al., 2012;Cardoso and Corte-Real, 2005;Witharana et al., 2014). The optimal parameter is selected based on the segmentation results that are most similar to the reference segmentation objects. For instance, Witharana and Civco (2014) measures the discrepancy by Euclidean distance 2 (ED2) to discriminate the quality of image objects. The optimal scale is selected when the ED2 is close to zero. Unfortunately, it is always time-consuming to generate the reference objects for supervised scale optimization. Thus, researchers start to focus on unsupervised approaches. The unsupervised approaches do not use reference objects and tend to design a measure to evaluate the quality of segmentation results at different scales (Espindola et al., 2006;Karl and Maurer, 2010;Stein and de Beurs, 2005;Zhou et al., 2017;Georganos et al., 2018b;Hu et al., 2016). Therefore, it is a key step to design an appropriate measurement for optimization methods. For example, the intra-region homogeneity and inter-region heterogeneity are employed as measurements to search the suitable objects until some conditions are satisfied (Drǎguţ et al., 2010). In Yang et al. (2015b), the average local variance of objects is introduced to measure the object homogeneity. However, the single scale parameter selected by the optimization methods still cannot satisfy the segmentation need due to the varying land covers of HR images. In some condition, the objects could be limited by the same scale parameter, no matter how homogeneous these objects are when compared with other objects. Ideally, the scale parameter should be adaptive to different regions or land covers. Specifically, in the urban area of an HR image, the scale parameter could be small to fit the building objects; while in the sea or water bodies, the scale parameter might be relatively large.

Recently, to overcome the limitation of single scale parameter, the cross-scale strategy has emerged and drawn attention in the scale optimization (Johnson and Xie, 2011;Zhang et al., 2015b;Chen et al., 2009). This strategy aims at fusing the multiple scale segmentation objects and generate a comprehensive segmentation results with adaptive scales at different land covers. At present, two groups of solutions are applied for multiscale optimization. One solution is to introduce land-cover categories to guide the selection of optimal scales (Myint et al., 2011). The optimal scales are obtained in different land cover categories and then synthesized as a multiscale segmentation results (Yi et al., 2012). The drawback of this method is that the land cover categories are difficult to obtain because we need either supervised information or classification rules in advance. Another solution is to select an initial scale to refine the single-scale segmentation Fig. 1. Flowchart of proposed optimization method. For example, in Johnson and Xie (2011), a global optimal scale is first selected from multiscale segmentation results. Then the improvement is conducted on under-segmentation and over-segmentation regions, respectively. At last, an optimal segmentation result can be combined with the improved segmentation regions. More recently, Su (2019) estimated a global scale for coarse segmentation first and then used region merging to further refine the segmentation result. Other studies try to optimize segmentation at several distinct scales (Yang et al., 2014). For instance, in Ming et al. (2015), the attribute of bandwidth and object shape are also employed in unsupervised scale optimization.

In this study, a novel unsupervised cross-scale optimization method is proposed for HR image segmentation. In order to fully exploit the spatial information in GEOBIA analysis, a local spectral heterogeneity measure is developed to search the optimal objects from segmentation results with different scales. At first, we calculate the local spectral heterogeneity for every object at each scale. Then the local spectral heterogeneity curves of corresponding objects at different scales can be obtained. We select the optimal scale at the largest value of the curve. Finally, the selected objects are synthesized as the segmentation result. The main contributions of the proposed method are twofold: 1) A local spectral homogeneity measure is proposed to evaluate the intra-object and inter-object heterogeneity through spectral angle analysis. 2) Different from refining the segmentation results on a global optimal scale, this study aims to directly search the optimal objects at different scales. Then final segmentation results are fused by the selected optimal objects. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method provides promising segmentation results over different land cover types.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we present the proposed optimal scale optimization method. Section 3 gives the study area and experimental results. The discussion and conclusion are described in Sections 4 and 5.

div.head: Methodology
div.p: The objective of this paper is to develop an unsupervised multiscale segmentation optimization method by measuring the local spectral heterogeneity for HR images. Fig. 1 depicts the framework of the proposed method. At first, a segmentation algorithm is applied to generate segmentation results of different scales. Then the objects are used to construct the region-adjacent graphs (RAG), which are built to specify the relationships between the neighboring objects. Second, a local spectral heterogeneity measure is proposed to evaluate every object at different scales. The optimal scale for the object is selected at the largest value of heterogeneity curve. Finally, the optimal objects selected from different scales are combined as segmentation result.

div.head: Multiscale segmentation used
div.p: A region based multiscale image segmentation named MSEG (Tzotsos and Argialas, 2006) is used to generate the initial segmentation results for HR images. MSEG is developed from the multi-resolution segmentation (Benz et al., 2004). It initially generates an oversegmentation result and then merge the segmentation objects in every iteration to achieve the final segmentation result. The criterion for object merging is a homogeneity cost measure, defined as object heterogeneity, and computed based on spectral and shape features for each possible object to merge. The heterogeneity is then compared to a user defined size (scale parameter) to decide whether the merge is continued in next iteration. The general function is formulated as follows:

When the size of objects reaches the defined scale parameter, the merging process stops and segmentation result is obtained. Fig. 2 depicts the process of generating multiscale segmentation results at different scales. As the algorithm merges small objects according to the preset scale parameter, the multiscale segmentation results can be generated at different scales with the objects merging. In addition, as shown in Fig. 2, the locations of objects at different scales are nested. Otherwise the boundaries of objects at different scales would be conflicting when combining the objects in optimization process.

The reflectance of individual pixel is represented as a B dimensional spectral vector, where B is the number of spectral bands. As each spectral vector has a direction, the spectral distance between two spectral vectors can be measured by spectral angle. Usually, the larger the spectral angle is, the more two spectral vectors are different.

div.head: Optimal object selection and combination
div.p: Since we have developed the local spectral measure for an object, the rest thing is to search the multiscale segmentation results and find the optimal object. To find the optimal object, a local heterogeneity curve is formed. Let z be a pixel of the HR image and m n ( , ) is the corresponding position. Then we can gather the objects that containing the pixel z with scale from 1 to L. For these objects that containing pixel z, an object evolution curve can be generated by calculating the local spectral heterogeneity. In the end, the corresponding optimal object is determined at the highest spectral heterogeneity E. Figs. 3 and 4 illustrate the optimal scale selection process of the pond object I1 and bare land object I2, respectively.

The object evolution curve can be generated at each position of an HR image. Therefore, the final segmentation result can be combined by all the selected objects. The combined scale map is shown in Fig. 1. The details of this method are listed in Table 1. It is worth mentioning that there are no conflicts when we combine the selected objects. As the multiscale segmentation method merges small objects by iteration, the selected objects are all nested. Specially, for an object s i that is included in a larger object s j , if the heterogeneity E of s j achieves highest E in the large region but E of s i is higher than that of s j , then both s i and s j are preserved as selected optimal objects in this region.

div.head: Quality assessment
div.p: In this study, besides visual analysis, a supervised segmentation evaluation method is used to assess the segmentation objects quality after scale optimization. The supervised segmentation evaluation method need a reference segmentation results as ground truth (Su and Zhang, 2017;Böck et al., 2017). A number of segmentation performance indexes such as global score, Moran index, have been applied in segmentation evaluation (Johnson and Xie, 2011;Zhang et al., 2012). Recently, a region-based precision and recall index (Zhang et al., 2015a) is specially proposed for evaluating the segmentation performance of remotely sensed images. The precision and recall index are calculated based on the objects overlapping. The precision index reflects the quality of segments and the recall index indicates the manner in which the reference objects are described by segments.

div.head: Segmentation optimization methods for comparison
div.p: In this study, an unsupervised multiscale segmentation optimization algorithm (Johnson and Xie, 2011) is used in comparison with the proposed method. In Johnson & Xie's method, a global scale is first identified by calculating the inter-segment and intra-segment heterogeneity with weighted variance and Moran's I. Then a refinement is conducted by further improving the under-segmented and over-segmented regions.

Apart from the cross-scale optimization mehtod, we also compare the proposed method with two global scale selection approaches. div.head: Experimental setup
div.p: The test area is located in Qingdao City, Shandong Province. Qingdao is a beautiful coastal city with various landscapes in East China. In this study, four test scenes (denoted as A, B, C and D), captured from QuickBird-2 with a resolution of 2.4 m on June 28, 2008, are used to evaluate the proposed optimization performance. All the scenes consist of four spectral bands (blue, green, red and near-infrared). As shown in Fig. 5, the test images contain different land covers, such as sea, raft culture ponds, coastal aquaculture ponds, farm land and urban built-ups. The corresponding reference segmentation objects are edited manually for supervised evaluation and are displayed in Fig. 5. Scene A has a size of × 600 600 pixels and Scene B has a size of × 700 700 pixels. Both Scene C and D have a size of × 500 500 pixels. The multiscale segmentation used in this study is MSEG algorithm (Tzotsos and Argialas, 2006), which is implemented under C++ environment in a computer with an intel i7-6700 CPU (3.4Ghz) and 16G RAM. For the sake of consistency, the shape and compactness parameters required in the algorithm are fixed to 0.4 and 0.5, respectively. The segmentation algorithm is performed with the scale parameter increasing from 10 to 400 at an interval of 10. The proposed optimization method and competitive methods described in Section 2 are implemented in the same computer with Matlab 2018a.

div.head: Optimal scales selection
div.p: As mentioned in Section 2, the optimal scale of each object is determined by the maximum value of local heterogeneity curve. In Fig. 6, we depict the local heterogeneity curves of different land covers, such as sea (Scene A), ponds (Scene A), aquaculture ponds (Scene B), vegetation (Scene C), farm land (Scene C) and bare land (Scene D). The corresponding positions (pixel coordinates) in test scenes are also listed in Fig. 6. From Fig. 6, we can clearly observe the evolution process of E s in different land covers. For example, for the sea and ponds objects in Scene A, the largest values fall at the scale of 400 and 350, respectively. The result is consistent with our intuition that the object scale of sea is larger than ponds. Similarly, the optimal scale for aquaculture ponds in Scene B falls at 110. We can also observe some rapid change of intraheterogeneity (Fig. 6 (e)(f)) with the scale increasing, indicating that the interior of object could have significantly different spectral vectors. This is possible that the object contains different land covers as the object may be under-segmented with the increase of scale. Fig. 7 depicts the obtained scale maps over the test scenes. As shown in Fig. 7, the blue color indicates a large optimal scale for the region while a red color indicates a small optimal scale. As the objects in Scene C and D mostly consist farm lands and buildings, the optimal scale for the objects are relatively small, which is consistent with the corresponding scale maps. In contrast, the optimal scales of Scene A (Fig. 7(a)) mainly fall at large scales because the scale for sea area is large.

div.head: Segmentation evaluation
div.p: To evaluate the optimization performance, the Johnson & Xie's method (Johnson and Xie, 2011) and two global optimization approaches (E-global and F-global) are used in comparison with our proposed optimization method. Table 2 reports the details about the optimization methods applied over test scenes. Five basic indexes are recorded in Table 2, including the number of objects, size of the largest object (pixels), size of smallest object (pixels), average size of objects and the standard deviation of size of objects. As shown in Table 2, we can observe that there is a big gap between the largest and smallest size of objects in the proposed method. It is understandable as the result of proposed method is a combination of multiscale segmentation results while the results of E-global and F-global only have the information of one single scale. Table 2 also reports the E mean , precision, recall and F index of proposed method and other three optimization methods. From Table 2, we can observe that the proposed optimization method achieved highest value at F index and E mean over the four test scenes. The Johnson & Xie's method also shows the potentials of cross-scale optimization method. Compared with the supervised method F-global, Johnson & Xie's method achieves higher F over Scene B and D. However, the precision index of proposed method is usually lower while the recall is higher in comparison with other methods. In fact, according to the analysis in Zhang et al. (2015a), if an image is over-segmented, the precision index is higher and recall index is lower. Therefore, for some over-segmented results, such as Figs. 10(b)(c) and 12(a)(b), the precision indexes are obviously higher than the proposed, and the recall is clearly lower the proposed method. One the other hand, some undersegmented regions can be observed in the results of proposed method, such as Figs. 9(d) and 11(d), so the lower precision is achieved and the corresponding F value is close to that of Johnson & Xie's method and Fglobal method.

Fig. 8 depicts the F-measure at all scale parameters over four scenes. The F-measure of proposed method (red bar) is also compared with that of other segmentation results (blue bar). From Fig. 8, we can find that the optimal single scale is larger than 120 for Scene A and B while the optimal scales for Scene C and D are obviously smaller than 120. As Scene A and B contain large area of sea water, it is reasonable that the optimal scale is larger than Scene C and D. The same phenomenon can also be found in Table 2. In summary, the F-measure of proposed method is highest compared with all other multiscale segmentation results.

The segmentation results of proposed optimization method and three other approaches are shown in Figs. 9-12. Figs. 9 and 10 (Scene A and B) mainly show the segmentation results over the sea and aquaculture ponds area. In Scene A and B, the scales for sea and aquaculture ponds area are apparently different. The scale parameter for sea area is obviously larger than the scale of aquaculture ponds. From Figs. 9(a)(b) and 10(a), the under-segmented regions for pond objects can be observed obviously, while the over-segmented sea object can be found in Figs. 9(c) and 10(b)(c). Compared with other scale optimization methods, the optimal scale for sea and aquaculture ponds are both reserved in the proposed method. In Figs. 9(d) and 10(d), the object boundaries of aquaculture ponds and sea area are well preserved. Fig. 11 (Scene C) displays the segmentation results over farm land and bare land. In Fig. 11, the farm lands are in regular shapes with different size of areas. We can observe that the objects of farm land are optimized in Fig. 11 (d), and the small objects on the bottom right of the image are well preserved. Scene D (Fig. 12) captured an urban area where buildings and playgrounds are distributed over the entire image. Obviously, the optimal scale for buildings is relatively small while the optimal scale for playgrounds is large. Fig. 12(b) shows a good segmentation in building while an over-segmented phenomenon is revealed in playgrounds. Similarly, an over-segmentation result in buildings is shown in Fig. 12(a). Fortunately, the different scale for buildings and playgrounds are optimized in Fig. 12(d).

div.head: Computational cost
div.p: The computational burden is also analyzed over four test scenes. According to the previous analysis, we can find that the computational cost mainly consists of two parts: inter and intra heterogeneity. For the convenience of calculation, the spectral angle of adjacent objects calculated in inter-heterogeneity can be saved and used in intra-heterogeneity. Let the object number be N, and then the computational complexity of proposed method is O N ( ) 2 . Fig. 13 depicts the execution time of optimization methods over four HR image. From Fig. 13, we can observe that two single-scale optimization methods (E-global and Fglobal) spend least time over four scenes. Since both Johnson & Xie's and proposed method need to calculate the inter and intra heterogeneity for each object, the two methods spend more execution time than two single-scale methods. In Scene B (700 × 700 by pixel), the execution time of Johnson & Xie's method is up to 180 s. In Johnson & Xie's method, a refinement need to conduct by further splitting or merging objects. In contrast, the selected objects in proposed method are all generated in segmentation procedure. Therefore, the execution time of proposed method is reduced when compared with Johnson & Xie's method.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: With the development of airborne and satellite sensor technologies, detailed spatial information in HR remote sensing images are available to researchers. The HR images raise a challenge of segmenting different objects, from water bodies to farm lands and buildings. The multiscale segmentation offers a possibility of segmenting objects with a preset scale, which can be determined by users to control the average size of objects. Due to the spatial variation of HR images, optimal scale selection has become an interesting topic and various algorithms have been proposed to deal with it. Besides supervised based methods, unsupervised scale selection methods have drawn more attention (Böck et al., 2017;Gonçalves et al., 2019). Many studies consider that the spectral homogeneity and heterogeneity calculation can help decide the optimal scale of segmentation (Wang et al., 2019).

This study proposed a local spectral heterogeneity measure to calculate inter and intra heterogeneity of objects at different scale parameters. Fig. 6 shows the curves of local spectral heterogeneity, inter and intra heterogeneity. The curves report the evolution process of objects, where the optimal scale of objects can be determined by the maximum value. Figs. 3 and 4 depict the procedure of optimal objects selection, where the optimal scales for pond (I1) and bare land object (I2) are 350 and 200, respectively.

Many multiscale optimization methods focus on selecting a global scale to generate an overall goodness of segmentation objects. While the global scale gives an overall accurate segmentation results compared with other scales, it is still limited by the fact that the single scale would be applied to all land covers, such as sea, ponds, farm land and buildups, regardless how heterogeneous they are to each other. To overcome this limitation, two groups of solutions are proposed recently. The first solution attempts to guide the optimal scales with different land cover, which requires land covers classification before scale selection (Yi et al., 2012). Another solution tries to optimize the segmentation with more than one scale (Xiao et al., 2018). In Johnson and Xie (2011) and Su (2019), an initial optimal scale is first selected and then further refinements are conducted to optimize the segmentation results.

The purpose of this proposed method is to directly find the optimal objects that could fit the land covers with a large scale gap. Through the proposed local spectral heterogeneity measure, these optimal objects are selected from segmentation results of different scales, and then combined as the final output. In the optimization results, both small and large objects can be preserved and delineated. For example, in Fig. 9, the large area of sea water and small size of ponds are described properly. We can also validate this observation by the difference between the size of largest and smallest object in Table 2. Segmentation quality assessment measure demonstrates that the proposed method can select objects that make a good match with the reference objects. As shown in Table 2, the proposed method achieves highest F value compared with other optimization methods.

The local heterogeneity E is calculated based on the spectral angle analysis. With the scale increasing, the spectral differences between adjacent objects are also increasing significantly. Therefore, if the intraheterogeneity is low, it is possible that the maximum E value falls at a relatively higher scale, and this reason could limit the optimization performance of the proposed method. For instance, as displayed in Fig. 9(d), an under-segmented region can be observed in the bottom of the image. That is because this region is surrounded by the road objects, which have a strong spectral difference with the vegetation-land regions. Thus the maximum E falls at a larger scale and an under-segmented phenomenon could be observed.

Although the segmentation algorithm used in this study is based on multi-resolution segmentation (MSEG) (Benz et al. (2004); Tzotsos and Argialas, 2006), the proposed method is implemented independently and can be applied in other multiscale segmentation algorithms, such as mean shift (Comaniciu and Meer, 2002) and watershed segmentation (Li et al., 2010).

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: Segmentation optimization is a vital and challenging task in GEOBIA applications. In this study, an unsupervised adaptive scale optimization method is proposed for multiscale HR image segmentation. To select the optimal segmentation objects, a local spectral heterogeneity measure is applied by calculating the spectral angle between inter and intra objects. Then the spectral heterogeneity curves of objects can be generated. Obviously, the optimal scale falls at the largest value of local spectral heterogeneity. The selected optimal objects are merged as the optimization result. The proposed method is evaluated over four test HR images with different land covers, such as sea, aquaculture ponds, farm land and built-ups. Optimization results demonstrate that the proposed method is able to adaptively select appropriate scales for different landscapes. Further experiments are conducted with the supervised segmentation quality assessment by computing the precision, recall and F-measure. The segmentation quality indexes also suggest that the proposed optimization provides satisfactory segmentation results compared with some other optimization methods. The proposed method can be applied in other multiscale segmentation algorithms. In the future, we will further improve the optimization performance in segmentation.
